stimulusHtml: The figure shows a graph of acceleration ax as a function of position x for an object moving along the x-axis. Is the graph shown consistent with simple harmonic motion? Why or why not?
choicesHtml: Yes, because the magnitude of the acceleration is proportional to the displacement from equilibrium and its direction is opposite that of the displacement.
Yes, because the graph is linear and passes through the origin.
No, because the acceleration is negative when the displacement from equilibrium is positive, and positive when the displacement is negative.
No, because the acceleration is always decreasing with increasing position.
